;;文件 - 2023 年 8 月 11 日，雾霾笼罩了印度尼西亚雅加达的主要商业区。 （美联社照片/Dita Alangkara，档案）;
;

;国际研究人员的一项新研究表明，地球的九项健康指标中有六项超出了“人类安全运行空间”。该研究补充说，其余三项措施中有两项正朝着错误的方向发展。

;

;国际科学家在《科学进展》上发表了这项研究。他们说，地球的气候、生物多样性、土地、淡水、营养物污染和人造化合物都超出了“人类安全操作空间”。

;

;科学家们表示，只有酸度海洋的健康、空气的健康和臭氧层都在被认为安全的范围内。

;

;臭氧层主要位于大气层的高层，可防止危险的太阳辐射到达地球表面.

;

;但该研究警告说，海洋和空气污染都在朝着错误的方向发展。

;

;约翰·罗克斯特罗姆 (Johan Rockstrom) 是一位气候科学家，他帮助撰写了这项研究。他是德国波茨坦气候影响研究所所长。他说：“我们的情况非常糟糕。”他将地球比作一个虚弱的病人。

;

;2009 年，Rockstrom 和其他研究人员创建了九个“边界区域”，并利用对它们的测量来判断地球的健康状况。最新研究继续了 2015 年类似研究的研究。最新研究在不安全列表中添加了第六个区域。

;

;Rockstrom 表示，地球上的水已从安全变为“不安全”。 ”科学家们表示，这是由于河流径流造成的。他们表示，更好的测量和对问题的理解表明存在问题。

;
;;;文件 - 随着中西部三位数的高温指数持续上升，一名妇女在夕阳下的剪影，2023 年 8 月 20 日，密苏里州堪萨斯城。一项新研究称，地球正在超出其“人类安全运行空间”。 （美联社照片/Charlie Riedel，档案）;
;

;Rockstrom 表示，这些边界将决定地球的未来。他补充说，这九项措施已被其他研究“科学地确立”。如果地球能够;管理;这九项措施，地球或多或少是安全的。但事实并非如此，他说。

;

;这九项措施以不同的方式进行了比较。该团队使用计算机;模拟;来预测未来。例如，他们会根据地球平均温度的升高做出预测。研究小组发现，如果一个区域受到温度变化的严重影响，那么所有区域都会受到严重影响。研究小组还发现，如果一个领域得到改善，所有领域都会得到改善。

;

;科学家们表示，模拟表明，帮助气候变化的最有力方法之一是清理土地和拯救森林。研究称，将森林恢复到 20 世纪末的水平将提供自然区域来储存二氧化碳，而不是在空气中储存二氧化碳，因为二氧化碳会在空气中滞留热量。

;

;Rockstrom 补充说，生物多样性处于最令人不安的领域，但确实如此没有得到那么多的关注。

;

;但是，研究表明臭氧层正在改善。这表明，当世界及其领导人决定解决问题时，问题就可以得到解决。

;

;尼尔·多纳休 (Neil Donahue) 是卡内基梅隆大学化学和环境教授。他说，“在大多数情况下，我们知道如何做一些事情”来改善剩余的问题。

;

;一些生物多样性科学家，如杜克大学的斯图尔特·皮姆 (Stuart Pimm)，对 Rockstrom 的方法提出了质疑，称这些方法并不可行。价值不菲。

;

;格兰杰·摩根是卡内基梅隆大学环境工程教授，并未参与这项研究。他说，“专家们对于极限到底在哪里，或者地球上不同系统可能;相互作用;的程度没有达成一致，但我们已经非常接近了。”

;

;摩根说他经常说，如果我们不减少对地球的伤害，“我们就完蛋了。”他补充道，“这篇论文说我们更有可能被烤焦了。”

;

;我是 Gregory Stachel。

;

;

;;美国图书馆协会于 2023 年 9 月 20 日星期三报道称，学校和公共图书馆的数量可能会在 2023 年达到历史新高，超过 2022 年的创纪录速度。（美联社照片/Rick Bowmer，档案）;
;

;美国图书馆协会 (ALA) 表示美国的禁书和禁书尝试继续增加。该组织指出，目前的努力已从学校扩展到公共图书馆。

;

;ALA 表示，2023 年前 8 个月，图书馆资料和服务面临 695 项;挑战;，涉及 1,915 名长期以来，人们一直试图从学校图书馆中删除他们认为具有冒犯性的书籍。但 ALA 周三表示，今年，学校和向公众开放的图书馆面临的挑战几乎均等。

;

;黛博拉·考德威尔-斯通 (Deborah Caldwell-Stone) 是该协会知识自由办公室的负责人。她说：“;讽刺;是，有一些;审查员;说，那些不想从学校撤回书籍的人可以去公共图书馆。”; p>;

;ALA 将挑战定义为“向图书馆或学校提交的正式书面;投诉;，要求因内容或适当性而删除材料。”

;

;许多其中的挑战来自“自由妈妈”组织。该组织在全国范围内组织了行动，并呼吁家长对向儿童提供的书籍进行更多控制。

;

;“过去大约是一对一的;比例;，其中家长会抱怨某本书，就像在许多人反对《哈利·波特》的时代一样，”考德威尔-斯通说。 “现在有人出现在会议上，要求删除 100 本书。”

;

;今年早些时候，这家总部位于芝加哥的协会发布了年度最受欢迎的 10 本书清单。 2022 年遭到反对。其中许多涉及种族和/或 LGBTQ 问题。玛雅·科巴贝的《性别酷儿》位居榜首，其次是乔治·约翰逊的《所有男孩都不蓝》和诺贝尔文学奖获得者托尼·莫里森的《最蓝的眼睛》 .

;

;2023 年，教师和图书馆员受到了很多批评。

;

;在南卡罗来纳州的 Chapin 高中，一些学生表示，老师让他们感觉“;为自己是白人而感到羞耻。”他们说，老师布置他们阅读塔内西斯·科茨的《在世界与我之间》。这本书是一封写给他儿子的公开信，内容涉及警察对黑人的暴力行为。它于 2015 年荣获国家图书奖。学校将该书从学习计划中删除。

;

;在弗吉尼亚州弗兰特罗亚尔，当地官员正计划为塞缪尔斯公共图书馆削减资金。此举是在保守派对有关同性恋和变性问题的书籍提出投诉之后做出的。

;

;爱荷华州州长金·雷诺兹最近签署了一项法案，要求从学校图书馆删除描述性行为的书籍。

; >;

;美国图书馆协会反对图书禁令也导致一些社区撤回其会员资格或支持，其中包括怀俄明州坎贝尔县和德克萨斯州米德兰的当地图书馆。密苏里州官员宣布，在新法律限制年轻人购买被认为不适合儿童的书籍的能力后，该州将撤回对 ALA 的支持。

;

;“我认为这种;趋势;将会持续下去， ”考德威尔-斯通说，“至少在这些团体想要追寻整个;类别;书籍的同时。”

;

;我是费思·皮尔洛。

;

; Thu, 21 Sep 2023 06:07:03 +0800 Former Argentine Torture Center Added to UNESCO Heritagehttps://learningenglish.voanews.com/a/former-argentine-torture-center-added-to-unesco-heritage/7276382.html
;;2023 年 9 月 20 日星期三 21:58:00 GMT;
;;
;;阿根廷独裁统治期间失踪人员的照片挂在学生走过的墙上ESMA 博物馆和纪念遗址，2023 年 9 月 19 日。（美联社照片/Rodrigo Abd）;
;

;阿根廷欢迎联合国决定将前秘密拘留和酷刑中心列为世界遗产文化遗产。

;

;联合国教育、科学及文化组织 (UNESCO) 在沙特阿拉伯举行的会议本周同意将 ESMA 博物馆和纪念遗址列入“被认为对人类具有杰出价值”的地点名单中。前海军机械学院（ESMA）位于阿根廷首都布宜诺斯艾利斯。它包含阿根廷上一次独裁统治期间（1976 年至 1983 年）运营的最臭名昭著的非法拘留中心。它现在作为博物馆和更大的纪念场所运营，包括政府机构和人权组织的办公室。

; <阿根廷总统阿尔贝托·费尔南德斯在视频致辞中赞扬了教科文组织的决定。他说，必须保留这段记忆，“以便阿根廷没有人忘记或否认在那里经历的恐怖。”费尔南德斯后来于周二下午在纽约举行的联合国大会上表示。 ：“通过积极;保留;否认者想要;隐藏;的记忆，我们将防止这种痛苦;再次发生;。”

;
; ;;2023 年 9 月 19 日星期二，阿根廷布宜诺斯艾利斯，一名男子在阿根廷海军机械学院、ESMA、博物馆和纪念遗址的一个用作拘留和酷刑中心的大厅里走动。（美联社照片/ Rodrigo Abd);
;

;据估计，独裁统治期间，ESMA 约有 5,000 人被拘留。许多被拘留者遭受酷刑，后来失踪。它还安置了许多后来被称为“死亡航班”的飞机扔进海洋或河流的人。

;

;ESMA 还安置了从其他非法拘留中心带来的孕妇。他们一直被关在那里，直到分娩，他们的孩子后来被军官带走。

;

;阿根廷人权部长霍拉西奥·彼得拉加拉·科尔蒂 (Horacio Pietragalla Corti) 对承认该地点的决定表示赞赏。他表示，这是“对那些否认或试图淡化国家恐怖主义和上一个军民独裁政权罪行的人的强有力的回应。”阿根廷外交部在社交媒体上发布的一段视频显示，当他庆祝联合国教科文组织的决定时，他热泪盈眶。

;

;皮特拉加拉是被军官带走并以虚假身份抚养长大的婴儿之一。五月广场祖母组织通过基因检测发现了他的出生史，以及其他 132 名被盗婴儿的出生史。

;

;阿根廷在审判前独裁政权的罪行方面比任何其他拉丁美洲国家都做得更多。自 2006 年以来，它已经进行了近 300 次审判，所有审判都与反人类罪有关。

;

;ESMA 被列入世界遗产名录不仅代表了阿根廷。皮特拉加拉称这一认可是“向我们大陆上数千名失踪人员;致敬;。”

;

;我是 Caty Weaver。

; Thu, 21 Sep 2023 06:07:03 +0800 Google Links Bard AI Tool to Its Other Productshttps://learningenglish.voanews.com/a/google-links-bard-ai-tool-to-its-other-products/7276373.html
;;2023 年 9 月 20 日星期三 22:05:35 GMT;
;;
;;在此文件照片中，各种 Google 徽标显示在 Google 搜索中（9 月星期一） 2023 年 11 月，纽约。 （美联社照片/Richard Drew，档案）;
;

;Google 已将其 Bard 人工智能 (AI) 工具与其 Gmail 服务和其他公司产品相关联。这家总部位于美国的搜索引擎公司表示，这一变化将使其用户能够在不同的产品领域轻松使用人工智能技术。

;

;;巴德; 是一个聊天机器人，一个计算机驱动的系统，旨在与人类顺利交互并执行高级写作。此类工具也被称为“生成式人工智能”或“大型语言模型”。

;

;第一个广泛发布的聊天机器人是 ChatGPT。它由科技公司 OpenAI 去年年底推出。谷歌去年二月宣布推出 Bard 工具。此后不久，微软宣布正在重新设计其 Bing 搜索引擎，以纳入 OpenAI 的聊天机器人技术。微软已在 OpenAI 上投资了数十亿美元。

;

;谷歌在周二的一份声明中表示，它已经创建了一个系统，使用户可以将人工智能工具扩展到其他公司服务或应用程序。这将 Bard 技术引入了 Google 产品，包括 Gmail、Drive、YouTube、地图等。

;

;将 AI 工具扩展到其他 Google 应用程序的系统称为 Bard Extensions。用户可以决定要将 Bard 添加到哪些应用程序。您可以通过访问 Google Chrome 浏览器并;按照流程;激活新扩展程序来完成此操作。目前，Bard Extensions 仅提供英语版本。

;

;;在解释这一变化的声明;中，Google 对用户如何将 Bard 与其他应用程序一起使用进行了多种描述。例如，Gmail 用户可以要求 Bard 创建涉及特定主题的所有电子邮件的;摘要;。

;

;另一个示例是针对计划大型家庭旅行的人的可能解决方案。在这种情况下，一系列 Google 应用程序可以与 Bard 一起使用。

;

;用户可以要求 Bard 搜索 Gmail 邮件，从多个家庭成员的电子邮件中获取可用的旅行日期。同时，用户可以要求巴德使用 Google Flights 查找适合该行程的航班日期。 Bard 还可用于预订可用的酒店房间，并与 Google 地图连接，为每个人提供前往机场的路线。用户还可以使用 Bard 查找旅途中要做的事情的 YouTube 视频。

;

;Google 给出的另一个例子是 Bard 如何与其他应用程序链接来帮助某人寻找工作。在这种情况下，Google 建议要求巴德“从我的云端硬盘中找到我的;简历;，标题为 2023 年 6 月，并将其总结为简短的个人陈述。”

;

;另一个新的附加组件Bard 允许用户邀请其他人加入他们的 Bard;对话;。

;

;在其声明中，Google 还表示，它已经创建了一种方式，让用户;验证;信息是否有效Bard工具生成的结果是否正确。此举被视为谷歌为帮助用户克服对其人工智能系统返回虚假、过时或破坏性结果的担忧而做出的努力。

;

;谷歌称使用了巴德的“Google it”;按钮

;

;可以测试其结果的正确性。当人们使用此按钮时，巴德的结果将与同一主题的 Google 搜索结果进行比较。然后，巴德指出了自己的结果与 Google 搜索返回的信息相比的差异。

;

;Google 高级产品总监 Jack Krawczyk 告诉路透社，该公司认为添加此功能非常重要，可以帮助用户找到最真实的结果。

;

;“我们以一种在不自信时也会承认的方式呈现（巴德），”Krawczyk 说。他补充说，这一努力是 Google 目标的一部分，即建立用户对生成式 AI 工具的信任，同时让 Bard 对其性能负责。

;

;在宣布 Bard Extensions 时，Google 承诺通过阻止来保护用户的隐私。阻止其员工看到 Bard 从 Gmail 或 Drive 等应用程序获取的任何个人信息。该公司表示，还采取了措施，防止与 Bard 相关的数据被用来向用户投放广告或训练人工智能工具。

;

;Krawczyk 指出，目前，Bard 用户只能从其他 Google 获取信息应用。不过，他表示 Google 已经在与其他公司合作，以便将来能够将他们的应用程序连接到 Bard。

;

;我是 Bryan Lynn。

;

;

;

;;布莱恩·林恩 (Bryan Lynn) 根据美联社、路透社、法新社和谷歌的报道，为美国之音学习英语撰写了这篇报道。 ;

;

;

;

;;摘要;;– n. ;简短的描述，提供有关某事的主要事实或想法

;

; Thu, 21 Sep 2023 06:07:03 +0800 Strange-looking Tomato Can Still Be Tastyhttps://learningenglish.voanews.com/a/strange-looking-tomato-can-still-be-tasty/7266727.html
;;2023 年 9 月 19 日星期二 21:55:44 GMT;

;;理查德·吉尔 (Richard Gill) 提供的这张 2021 年 9 月的照片显示了北伦敦的一种带有基因突变的番茄，英格兰。 （理查德·吉尔 @happymrgill，美联社）;
;

;每年的这个时候，许多园丁都会收获西红柿。 ;美联社;园艺专家杰西卡·达米亚诺（Jessica Damiano）最近报道了她的园艺建议粉丝发给她的许多形状奇怪的西红柿的照片。她说，人们有时会质疑西红柿是否可以吃。

;

;达米亚诺说，好消息是，畸形的水果没有任何问题。除非有其他疾病，否则它们非常适合食用。它们不寻常的外观不会影响其味道或;营养;价值。

;

;;这是怎么回事？;

;

;如果您曾经切过打开番茄，你知道它们分为;内部;部分，称为小室，其中含有种子和一种称为凝胶的物质。大多数西红柿大约有四到五个小室；其他种类的水果，如樱桃番茄，则含有两种或三种。李子或罗马番茄有两个小室。

;
;;;2018 年 6 月 10 日，克劳迪娅·沃斯提供的图片显示了比利时阿尔斯霍特的一个带有基因突变的番茄。当番茄细胞由于炎热或寒冷的天气而异常分裂时，就会出现这种异常情况，导致在果实外长出额外的部分。 （克劳迪娅·沃斯，美联社）;
;

;但是，当植物经历极端温度时，正在发育的果实中的细胞分裂可能会偏离正轨。白天超过32摄氏度和夜间超过27摄氏度的温度会导致番茄形成额外的小室。但番茄内部没有足够的空间容纳多余的部分，因此它会生长在果实的外部。

;

;然而，并非受影响植物上的每个番茄都会变形。

;

;;可能性有多大？;

;

;“在适当的条件下（温度太热甚至太冷），这可能会影响每株植物的一到两个西红柿，具体取决于地点它们正处于开发过程中，（天气）条件如何，”蒂莫西·麦克德莫特说。他是俄亥俄州立大学的助理;教授;和推广教育家。

;

;您的一个西红柿出现;奇怪;小室的可能性约为麦克德莫特说，千分之一。

;

;任何番茄都可以长出额外的小室。但是，达米亚诺指出，;传家宝;品种似乎比;杂种;更有可能发生这种遗传;突变;。; ;

;
;;;这张由 Kathy Burrous 提供的 2022 年图像显示了纽约花卉公园的一个带有基因突变的番茄。当番茄细胞由于炎热或寒冷的天气而异常分裂时，就会出现这种异常情况，导致在果实外长出额外的部分。 （Kathy Burrous，来自美联社）;
;

;;热番茄？;

;

;小室外突变并不是极端高温引起的唯一异常。当植物在超出正常温度限制的情况下生长时，也会出现晒伤、;开花;掉落、果实形成停止和;成熟;等情况。

;

;提供;当气温预计连续几天保持在 32 摄氏度以上时，为您的植物提供遮荫。将一块 40% 至 50% 的遮阳布固定在插入植物周围地面的木桩上。中午 12 点到下午 4 点，当阳光最强烈时，将其放置在适当的位置。然后将其移除，以避免因缺乏阳光而引起的问题。

;

;而且，在收获作物时，请记住：看起来滑稽的西红柿味道也一样好！

;

;我是 Caty韦弗。

;

;

;

;;杰西卡·达米亚诺为美联社报道了这个故事。 Caty Weaver 将其改编为美国之音学习英语。;

;

;

;;奇怪; ;- n。 ;一些奇怪或不寻常的东西

;

;;传家宝; ; – adj。 ;一种栽培植物，通常由于个人的努力而存活了几代

;

;;突变;;– n。 ;变化，尤其是植物或动物的遗传变化，以某种方式影响其外观、功能或结构

;

;;文件 - 宾夕法尼亚州民主党参议员约翰·费特曼 (John Fetterman) 向媒体成员挥手致意2023 年 4 月 17 日，华盛顿国会山。 （美联社照片/Jacquelyn Martin，档案）;
;

;美国参议院多数党领袖本周表示，立法机构将不再在其会场强制执行着装规定。着装规范是一套关于可以穿什么、不可以穿什么的规则。

;

;多数党领袖、参议员查克·舒默 (Chuck Schumer) 在一份声明中表示，“参议员可以选择在参议院的着装。我将继续穿西装。”

;

;这一变化是在宾夕法尼亚州民主党参议员约翰·费特曼 (John Fetterman) 为避免违反着装规定而在参议院门口投票之后做出的。代码。虽然其他参议员在国会大厦穿着商务服装或礼服，但费特曼在工作时通常穿着短裤等非正式服装。

;

;舒默在有关着装要求的声明中没有谈论费特曼。但着装要求的放宽仅适用于参议员，不适用于其他雇员。

;

;在竞选美国参议院期间，费特曼中风，这是一种严重的疾病，当大脑得不到足够的支持时就会发生这种情况来自血液的氧气。今年早些时候，费特曼因抑郁症入院治疗。

;
;;;文件 - 2023 年 9 月 6 日，华盛顿，宾夕法尼亚州民主党参议员约翰·费特曼 (John Fetterman) 在国会山参议院地铁附近乘坐电梯时做手势。 （美联社照片/Mariam Zuhaib，档案）;
;

;当费特曼从治疗中回来时，他开始穿更多的休闲衣服，他说这让他更加;舒适。;;

;着装要求的改变遭到了参议院一些;正式;成员的反对。

;

;堪萨斯州共和党参议员罗杰·马歇尔 (Roger Marshall) 表示，这是一个“参议院悲伤的一天”，费特曼和舒默所代表的人民应该感到;尴尬;。

;

;缅因州共和党参议员苏珊·柯林斯表示同意，认为新规则抹黑了参议院代表。 “我计划明天穿比基尼去参议院，”柯林斯开玩笑说。比基尼是人们游泳时穿的衣服。

;

;费特曼表示，他还不确定是否会开始使用新规则。他说，很高兴将它们作为一种选择，但他计划不经常使用它们，也不会过度使用它们。

;

;费特曼谈到他的批评者时，“他们;吓坏了; 出来，我听不懂。”他说，他们应该做更重要的事情，而不是他的穿着。

;

;并非所有共和党人都对这一变化感到困扰。密苏里州参议员乔什·霍利 (Josh Hawley) 周一晚上穿着牛仔裤。他说，当他从家乡飞来参加本周的第一次投票时，他通常会穿着便服。

;

;“现在我可以在周一在参议院投票，”霍利说，并指出他通常每隔一天穿西装打领带。领带是一件正式服装。

;

;附近，康涅狄格州参议员克里斯·墨菲 (Chris Murphy) 也没有打领带。 The Democrat said he has gotten in trouble with the Senate's official clothes police, called Sergeant-at-Arms, in the past for not wearing a tie on the floor.

;

;“They would tell us when we were doing it wrong,” Murphy said.

;

;It is unclear if the rules for more formal wear were actually written down anywhere. But Schumer's statement means employees will no longer criticize senators for their choice of clothing or ask them to vote from the doorway.

;

;“I think we should all want to be more comfortable,” Fetterman told a group of reporters on Monday. He added that now that they have that choice, and if people want to wear a suit, “… then that's great.”

;I'm Gregory Stachel.

; Wed, 20 Sep 2023 06:07:03 +0800 India, Canada Expel Diplomats over Killing of Sikh Activisthttps://learningenglish.voanews.com/a/india-canada-expel-diplomats-over-killing-of-sikh-activist/7274927.html
;;Tue, 19 Sep 2023 21:58:00 GMT;

;;A sign outside the Guru Nanak Sikh Gurdwara temple is seen after the killing on its grounds in June 2023 of Sikh leader Hardeep Singh Nijjar, in Surrey, British Columbia, Canada September 18, 2023. (REUTERS/Chris Helgren);
;

;India expelled a Canadian diplomat Tuesday and accused Canada of interfering in its ;internal; affairs.

;

;The move came one day after Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau said his government was investigating a possible connection between India and the killing of a Sikh activist, Hardeep Singh Nijjar.

;

;Nijjar, a Canadian citizen, was an activist in the Sikh independence movement. He was shot to death on June 18 outside a Sikh cultural center in Surrey, British Columbia.

;

;Canada expelled a top Indian diplomat in protest.

;

;The Indian government has denied any involvement in Nijjar's killing. But Trudeau said, “We are simply laying out the facts as we understand them.” He added, “We want to work with the government of India to lay everything clear and to ensure there are proper processes.”

;

;India has repeatedly accused Canada of supporting the Sikh independence movement, called Khalistan. The movement is banned in India but has support among the Sikhs living in other countries.

;

;In 2020, the Hindu nationalist government of Prime Minister Narendra Modi called Nijjar a terrorist. Indian media reported that he was suspected of organizing a bombing in Punjab, India, and training terrorists in a small area near Vancouver, Canada.

;
;;;India Canada Sikh Slain;
;

;;What is the Khalistan movement?;

;

;The Sikh independence movement began as an armed ;insurgency; in the 1980s among Sikhs demanding a separate homeland. It was centered in northern Punjab state, where Sikhs are the majority. Sikhs make up about 1.7 percent of India's total population.

;

;In 1984, Indian forces attacked the Golden Temple, Sikhism's holiest religious center, in order to capture separatists who had taken refuge there. The government reported around 400 killed in the operation. But Sikh groups say thousands were killed. The dead included Sikh militant leader Jarnail Singh Bhindranwale, whom the Indian government accused of leading the armed insurgency.

;

;On October 31, 1984, Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, who ordered the attack on the temple, was ;assassinated; by two of her bodyguards, who were Sikhs.

;

;Her death led to several anti-Sikh riots. Crowds of Hindus went from house to house across northern India, pulling Sikhs from their homes and killing them.

;

;There is no active insurgency in Punjab today, but the Khalistan movement still has supporters in India and abroad. And Prime Minister Narendra Modi's government has also arrested leaders from groups that are linked to the movement.

;

;;How strong is the movement outside India?;

;

;India has been asking countries like Canada, Australia and Britain to take legal action against Sikh activists. India has raised these concerns with Canada, where 770,000 Sikhs make up nearly two percent of the country's population.

;

;Earlier this year, Sikh protesters removed an Indian flag and broke the window at the country's office in London to protest the arrest of a Sikh religious leader. Protesters also smashed windows at the Indian consulate in San Francisco and fought with embassy workers.

;

;The Indian government has accused Khalistan supporters in Canada of damaging Hindu temples with “anti-India” graffiti and of attacking India's diplomatic office in Ottawa during a protest in March.

;

;Last year, Paramjit Singh Panjwar, a Sikh militant leader and head of the Khalistan Commando Force, was shot dead in Pakistan.

;

;I'm Andrew Smith.

;

;

;

;;Hai Do adapted this report for VOA Learning English from Associated Press sources. ;

; Wed, 20 Sep 2023 06:07:03 +0800 Citizenship Test Changes Might Require Better English Skillshttps://learningenglish.voanews.com/a/citizenship-test-changes-might-require-better-english-skills/7273487.html
;;Tue, 19 Sep 2023 22:05:47 GMT;
;;
;;FILE - A participant from Bangladesh takes the Naturalization Oath of Allegiance to the United States of America, on June 30, 2017, during a naturalization ceremony at the New York Public Library in New York. (AP Photo/Michael Noble Jr.);
;

;The United States admitted over 967,000 people as new citizens in 2022.

;

;United States Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS) said that was the largest number of people ;naturalized; since 2008.

;

;To become a US citizen, a candidate needs to live in the country as a permanent ;resident; for at least five years and be over 18 years old. After applying, a candidate for citizenship needs to pass an interview with a USCIS officer.

;

;In the interview, an official ;assesses ;the person for their English ability, knowledge of American history and government, and personal background. Over 96 percent of people pass the naturalization test. But changes are coming to the test that could make it more difficult for English learners.

;

;Carolyn Quinn and John Schmelzer teach a free class in Montgomery County, Maryland, to help prepare people living in the area for the interview. They said it is most important that people are able to understand the questions the interviewer is asking. It is not as important to speak in grammatically correct sentences. The question the interview is trying to answer is: “Do these people understand enough English to be a ;functioning; citizen?” Schmelzer said.

;

;At the beginning of each class, Quinn and Schmelzer ask their students simple “small talk” questions they might hear in the interview, like “How did you get here today?” or “Why do you want to become a United States citizen?” Much of the interview is based on questions on the Application for Naturalization Form, called the ;N-400;. Most are personal questions related to employment, family and personal history.

;

;Rajbit Kahn took Quinn's class and passed the naturalization interview in August. She said the class gave her more ;confidence; to speak English in the interview. Before the class, she rarely spoke English, she said. But now, “I talk to anyone.”

;

;However, Quinn stresses to her students that her class is not an English class. And she has students enter her class without enough English knowledge to pass the interview.

;

;With the increase in Afghan immigrants into the United States, Quinn said she has had a few Afghan women come into her class. She said, “They never had any kind of schooling. So, they don't know how to write. They don't know how to read. They don't know letter sounds.” Often, family members with better English skills will fill out the N-400 ;form; for them. But they would be unable to answer the interview questions themselves.

;

;Possible changes to the naturalization interview would make civics questions multiple choice to “reflect current best practices in test design,” USCIS said in a document explaining the update to the test. Schmelzer said that would make the test harder for immigrants who may not have a great understanding of American history or English.

;

;For now, students memorize 100 ;civics; questions. Ten of the questions will be asked on the day of the interview and applicants must answer six correctly to pass. One question is “Name one war fought by the United States in the 1800s.” Currently, people just need to memorize one war fought during that 100-year period. But a multiple-choice test would require knowledge of four wars presented as answer choices and know which one was fought in the 1800s.

;

;“You're forcing them to expand their memorization,” Schmelzer said.

;
;;;Maria Valles Bonilla, 106, right, recites the Oath of Allegiance during a naturalization ceremony at US Citizenship and Immigration Services office, Tuesday, Nov. 6, 2018, in Fairfax, Va. (9AP Photo/Pablo Martinez Monsivais);
;

;Another proposed change would add a speaking test to assess English ability. The officer would present three photos and the interviewee would have to describe what is happening in the pictures. Currently, English knowledge is assessed through questions from the N-400 and other small-talk questions.

;

;The new interview changes are currently being tested in several locations around the country. USCIS will hear ;feedback; about the tests before the end of the year.

;

;Quinn and Schmelzer said the test should be updated. Just one civics question is related to a female American historical figure, Schmelzer said.

;

;But Quinn questions what is to be gained by making changes to the test to make it harder.

;

;People in her class “put their souls” into becoming citizens. “How much more do we need to ask them to do?” she said.

;

;John Yepow is another of Quinn's students who along with his wife, recently became a US citizen. Yepow came from the Democratic Republic of Congo. He lived in Zambia for 10 years before moving to the United States.

;

;Yepow, who works as a medication technician, said he follows American politics closely. He calls himself a lifelong learner and has even taken online classes about American history.

;

;“I want to learn and make sure I'm ;integrated; into American society,” he said.

;

;Yepow added: “This is the land of ;opportunity;. We are dreaming big." He said he will make sure to ;take advantage ;of every opportunity."

;

;I'm Anna Mateo

;

;And I'm Dan Novak.

;

;

;

;;Dan Novak wrote this story for VOA Learning English.;

;

;

;

;;In this photo published August 11, 2022 shows the spokesman of the Iranian Ministry of the Exterior. (Iranian Ministry of the Exterior, via AP Archives);
;

;US Secretary of State Antony Blinken announced that seven Americans have been released by Iran after the nations agreed to a prisoner exchange also involving Qatar and South Korea.

;

;South Korea said on Monday it is working with the United States and Iran to release restrictions on $6 billion of frozen Iranian money. The US is releasing the money as part of the prisoner exchange.

;

;The money is being ;transferred; to Qatar. Then, seven people with ;dual; US citizenship, who have been imprisoned or detained in Iran, are expected to leave Tehran for Doha. Officials told ;Reuters ;news service that, from there, they will travel to the United States. Qatar ;mediated; the deal during months of talks.

;

;In return, five Iranians detained in the US will be released so they can travel to Iran. Iranian officials and Iran's state news agency have said one of those detainees is expected to remain in the United States.

;

;The exact timing of the transfer of the money has yet to be announced.

;

;The deal was first made public on August 10. But the countries continue to disagree on many issues. They include Iran's nuclear program, Iran's effort to influence the Persian Gulf area, US ;sanctions; and America's military presence in the Persian Gulf.

;

;South Korea is “currently making efforts to ensure smooth progress of all procedures so that it will be resolved once and for all," the country's foreign ministry said in a statement.

;

;The US dual citizens to be released include 51-year-old Siamak Namazi and 59-year-old Emad Sharqi, both businessmen, and 67-year-old Morad Tahbaz, an environmentalist. Tahbaz also holds British nationality. Iran released them from prison and put them under house arrest last month.

;

;A fourth US citizen was also released into house arrest, while a fifth was already under house arrest. Their identities have not been released.

;

;Iranian officials named the five Iranians to be released by the US as: Mehrdad Moin-Ansari, Kambiz Attar-Kashani, Reza Sarhangpour-Kafrani, Amin Hassanzadeh and Kaveh Afrasiabi. Two Iranian officials said Afrasiabi would remain in the United States.

;

;As a first step in the deal, the United States suspended sanctions to permit the transfer of $6 billion in Iranian money from South Korea to Qatar. The money had been blocked in South Korea, which is normally one of Iran's largest oil buyers, because of US sanctions.

;

;Under the agreement, Qatar agreed to ;monitor; how Iran uses the money to ensure it goes to non-sanctioned humanitarian goods, like food and medicine.

;

;The transfer of Iran's money has faced criticism from US lawmakers including opposition Republican Party members. They said the deal is equal to paying a ;ransom; for US citizens. The administration of President Joe Biden has defended the deal.

;

;Qatar held at least eight sets of talks involving Iranian and US negotiators. The negotiators worked from separate hotels. People told ;Reuters; that they exchanged proposals through Qatari mediators. Earlier talks dealt mainly with the nuclear issue. Later, talks turned to the prisoner releases.

;

;I'm Caty Weaver.

;

;

;

;Small farms with natural trees and forests that block sunlight can provide a refuge for some bird populations, a study in Costa Rica found.

;

;For 18 years, bird expert James Zook has been collecting records on nearly 430 kinds of ;tropical ;birds found on farms and natural forests in the Central American country.

;

;While birds do best in natural rainforests, Zook said some ;species; usually found in forests can establish populations in “diversified farms.” Diversified farms are farms that contain areas similar to a natural forest environment.

;

;“How you farm matters,” said Nicholas Hendershot. He is a Stanford University environmental scientist. He helped write the study published recently in ;Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences.;

;

;“In these diversified farms, you see growth over the long term in bird species with specialized needs,” Hendershot said. These specialized needs include safe and protected areas from the sun for birds to build their homes and different kinds of food sources.

;

;That kind of farming is very different to industrial agriculture or agriculture where only one crop like pineapple or bananas are planted, he said.

;

;Natalia Ocampo-Penuela is a University of California, Santa Cruz environmental scientist who was not involved in the study. She said the findings may seem to make sense without research. But she added that it is very rare to have detailed data over a long time from tropical areas to show that diversified farming can support some forest bird populations.

;
;;;This photo provided by researchers in September 2023 shows a diversified farm in Finca, Coto Brus, Costa Rica. (Gretchen C. Daily via AP);
;

;“With 18 years of data, you can show the species is ;persisting; in that area, not simply passing by,” she said.

;

;Of the 305 species found in diversified farms, 75 percent showed ;stable; or growing populations over the time of study. These include birds like the collared aracari as well as several members of the manakin family – colorful birds known for their complex mating dances.

;

;Ruth Bennett is a scientist at the Smithsonian Migratory Bird Center. She was not involved in the research. She said, “It's a huge ;contribution; to have documented that some birds aren't just going there, but staying there and populations are growing,”

;

;Still, such safe environments, called habitats, do not balance out overall population losses from the creation of large industrial farms from natural forests, the writers warned. Zook compared a large pineapple farm to a “bird desert.”

;

;Increasingly, scientists say saving species will require paying attention to areas affected by humans, not just untouched areas.

;

;Ocampo-Penuela said modern efforts to save species have to happen not only inside protected areas, but also within agricultural areas and even cities. She said these efforts have to happen where there is at least a possibility that some species could live there.

;

;I'm Greg Stachel.
